Avoid the Columbian Exchange: The Columbian Exchange, which occurred in the late 15th century, was a pivotal event in world history where the Old World (Europe and Africa) and the New World (the Americas) exchanged plants, animals, and diseases. This event led to the devastation of indigenous populations and ecosystems, as well as the creation of new crops and agricultural practices. If I could change one historical event, I would choose to prevent the Columbian Exchange, as it would have spared countless lives and ecosystems from destruction.

Prevent the French Revolution: The French Revolution, which began in 1789 and lasted for over a decade, was a period of immense social, political, and cultural upheaval in France. While it led to the establishment of the modern French state and the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen, it also led to the Reign of Terror, the rise of Napoleon, and the loss of countless lives. If I could change one historical event, I would choose to prevent the French Revolution, as it would have spared France and the world from these devastating consequences.

Stop the Holocaust: The Holocaust, which occurred during World War II, was the systematic persecution and murder of six million Jews and millions of others deemed undesirable by the Nazi regime. This event is one of the darkest moments in human history, and its impact on the world is still felt today. If I could change one historical event, I would choose to stop the Holocaust, as it would have spared countless lives and prevented one of the most heinous crimes in human history.

Prevent the Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster, which occurred in 1986, was the worst nuclear accident in history, releasing radioactive materials into the environment and causing widespread contamination. If I could change one historical event, I would choose to prevent the Chernobyl disaster, as it would have spared countless lives and prevented a catastrophic environmental disaster.
